text: The word of the Lord that came to Hosea son of Beeri, in the days of Kings Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah of Judah and in the days of King Jeroboam son of Joash of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord first spoke through Hosea, the Lord said to Hosea, “Go, take for yourself a wife of prostitution and have children of prostitution, for the land commits great prostitution by forsaking the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went and took Gomer daughter of Diblaim, and she conceived and bore him a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said to him, “Name him Jezreel, for in a little while I will punish the house of Jehu for the blood of Jezreel, and I will put an end to the kingdom of the house of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day I will break the bow of Israel in the Valley of Jezreel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She conceived again and bore a daughter. Then the Lord said to him, “Name her Lo-ruhamah, for I will no longer have pity on the house of Israel or forgive them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will have pity on the house of Judah, and I will save them by the Lord their God; I will not save them by bow or by sword or by war or by horses or by horsemen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When she had weaned Lo-ruhamah, she conceived and bore a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said, “Name him Lo-ammi, for you are not my people, and I am not your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet the number of the people of Israel shall be like the sand of the sea, which can be neither measured nor numbered, and in the place where it was said to them, “You are not my people,” it shall be said to them, “Children of the living God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Judah and the people of Israel shall be gathered together, and they shall appoint for themselves one head, and they shall rise up from the land, for great shall be the day of Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to your brothers, “Ammi,” and to your sisters, “Ruhamah.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Plead with your mother, plead—
    for she is not my wife,
    and I am not her husband—
that she put away her prostitution from her face
    and her adultery from between her breasts,
speaker: Narrator

text:
or I will strip her naked
    and expose her as in the day she was born
and make her like a wilderness
    and turn her into a parched land
    and kill her with thirst.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Upon her children also I will have no pity,
    because they are children of prostitution.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Therefore I will hedge up her way with thorns,
    and I will build a wall against her
    so that she cannot find her paths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She shall pursue her lovers
    but not overtake them,
and she shall seek them
    but shall not find them.
Then she shall say, “I will go
    and return to my first husband,
    for it was better with me then than now.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
She did not know
    that it was I who gave her
    the grain, the wine, and the oil
and who lavished upon her silver
    and gold that they used for Baal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I will take back
    my grain in its time
    and my wine in its season,
and I will take away my wool and my flax,
    which were to cover her nakedness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now I will uncover her shame
    in the sight of her lovers,
    and no one shall rescue her out of my hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will put an end to all her mirth,
    her festivals, her new moons, her Sabbaths,
    and all her appointed festivals.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will lay waste her vines and her fig trees,
    of which she said,
“These are my pay,
    which my lovers have given me.”
I will make them a forest,
    and the wild animals shall devour them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will punish her for the festival days of the Baals,
    to whom she offered incense
and decked herself with her rings and jewelry
    and went after her lovers
    and forgot me, says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, I will now allure her
    and bring her into the wilderness
    and speak tenderly to her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From there I will give her her vineyards
    and make the Valley of Achor a door of hope.
There she shall respond as in the days of her youth,
    as at the time when she came out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day, says the Lord, you will call me “my husband,” and no longer will you call me “my Baal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For I will remove the names of the Baals from her mouth, and they shall be mentioned by name no more.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make for you a covenant on that day with the wild animals, the birds of the air, and the creeping things of the ground, and I will abolish the bow, the sword, and war from the land, and I will make you lie down in safety.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will take you for my wife forever; I will take you for my wife in righteousness and in justice, in steadfast love and in mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take you for my wife in faithfulness, and you shall know the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On that day I will answer, says the Lord,
    I will answer the heavens,
    and they shall answer the earth,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and the earth shall answer the grain, the wine, and the oil,
    and they shall answer Jezreel,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and I will sow him for myself in the land.
And I will have pity on Lo-ruhamah,
    and I will say to Lo-ammi, “You are my people,”
    and he shall say, “You are my God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to me again, “Go, love a woman who has a lover and is an adulteress, just as the Lord loves the people of Israel, though they turn to other gods and love raisin cakes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I bought her for fifteen shekels of silver and a homer of barley and a measure of wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I said to her, “You must remain as mine for many days; you shall not prostitute yourself; you shall not have intercourse with a man, nor I with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Israelites shall remain many days without king or prince, without sacrifice or pillar, without ephod or teraphim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward the Israelites shall return and seek the Lord their God and David their king; they shall come in awe to the Lord and to his goodness in the latter days.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear the word of the Lord, O people of Israel,
    for the Lord has an indictment against the inhabitants of the land.
There is no faithfulness or loyalty
    and no knowledge of God in the land.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Therefore the land mourns,
    and all who live in it languish;
together with the wild animals
    and the birds of the air,
    even the fish of the sea are perishing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet let no one contend,
    and let none accuse,
    for with you is my contention, O priest.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
My people are destroyed for lack of knowledge!
    Because you have rejected knowledge,
    I reject you from being a priest to me;
and since you have forgotten the law of your God,
    I also will forget your children.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They feed on the sin of my people;
    they are greedy for their iniquity.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They shall eat but not be satisfied;
    they shall prostitute themselves but not multiply,
because they have forsaken the Lord
to devote themselves to
speaker: Narrator

text:
prostitution.
Wine and new wine
    take away the understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My people consult a piece of wood,
    and their divining rod gives them oracles.
For a spirit of prostitution has led them astray,
    and they have prostituted themselves, forsaking their God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They sacrifice on the tops of the mountains
    and make offerings upon the hills,
under oak, poplar, and terebinth
    because their shade is good.
Therefore your daughters prostitute themselves,
    and your daughters-in-law commit adultery.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will not punish your daughters when they prostitute themselves
    nor your daughters-in-law when they commit adultery,
for the men themselves go aside with prostitutes
    and sacrifice with female attendants;
thus a people without understanding comes to ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though you prostitute yourself, O Israel,
    do not let Judah become guilty.
Do not enter into Gilgal
    or go up to Beth-aven,
    and do not swear, “As the Lord lives.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a stubborn heifer,
    Israel is stubborn;
can the Lord now feed them
    like a lamb in a broad pasture?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ephraim is joined to idols—
    let him alone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When their drinking is ended, they indulge in sexual orgies;
    they love lewdness more than their glory.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wind has wrapped them in its wings,
    and they shall be ashamed because of their altars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear this, O priests!
    Give heed, O house of Israel!
Listen, O house of the king!
    For the judgment pertains to you,
for you have been a snare at Mizpah
    and a net spread upon Tabor
speaker: Narrator

text:
and a pit dug deep in Shittim,
    but I will punish all of them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I know Ephraim,
    and Israel is not hidden from me,
for now, O Ephraim, you have prostituted yourself;
    Israel is defiled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their deeds do not permit them
    to return to their God.
For the spirit of prostitution is within them,
    and they do not know the Lord.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
With their flocks and herds they shall go
    to seek the Lord,
but they will not find him;
    he has withdrawn from them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have dealt faithlessly with the Lord,
    for they have borne illegitimate children.
    Now the new moon shall devour them along with their fields.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blow the horn in Gibeah,
    the trumpet in Ramah.
Sound the alarm at Beth-aven;
    look behind you, Benjamin!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ephraim shall become a desolation
    in the day of punishment;
among the tribes of Israel
    I declare what is sure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The princes of Judah have become
    like those who remove the landmark;
on them I will pour out
    my wrath like water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ephraim is oppressed, crushed in judgment,
    because he was determined to go after vanity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I am like maggots to Ephraim
    and like rottenness to the house of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Ephraim saw his sickness
    and Judah his wound,
then Ephraim went to Assyria
    and sent to the great king.
But he is not able to cure you
    or heal your wound.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I will be like a lion to Ephraim
    and like a young lion to the house of Judah.
I myself will tear and go away;
    I will carry off, and no one shall rescue.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will return again to my place
    until they acknowledge their guilt and seek my face.
    In their distress they will beg my favor:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
What shall I do with you, O Ephraim?
    What shall I do with you, O Judah?
Your love is like a morning cloud,
    like the dew that goes away early.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For I desire steadfast love and not sacrifice,
    the knowledge of God rather than burnt offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But at Adam they transgressed the covenant;
    there they dealt faithlessly with me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gilead is a city of evildoers,
    tracked with blood.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
In the house of Israel I have seen a horrible thing;
    Ephraim’s prostitution is there; Israel is defiled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you also, O Judah, a harvest is appointed.
When I would restore the fortunes of my people,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when I would heal Israel,
    the corruption of Ephraim is revealed,
    and the wicked deeds of Samaria,
for they deal falsely;
    the thief breaks in,
    and the bandits raid outside.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But they do not consider
    that I remember all their wickedness.
Now their deeds surround them;
    they are before my face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By their wickedness they make the king glad,
    and the officials by their treachery.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are all adulterers;
    they are like a heated oven
whose baker does not need to stir the fire
    from the kneading of the dough until it is leavened.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
All of them are hot as an oven,
    and they devour their rulers.
All their kings have fallen;
    none of them calls upon me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ephraim mixes himself with the peoples;
    Ephraim is a cake not turned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Foreigners devour his strength,
    but he does not know it;
gray hairs are sprinkled upon him,
    but he does not know it.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Woe to them, for they have strayed from me!
    Destruction to them, for they have rebelled against me!
I would redeem them,
    but they speak lies against me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
It was I who trained and strengthened their arms,
    yet they plot evil against me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Set the trumpet to your lips!
    One like a vulture is over the house of the Lord,
because they have broken my covenant
    and transgressed my law.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They cry to me,
    “My God, we know you!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Israel has spurned the good;
    the enemy shall pursue him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They made kings but not through me;
    they set up princes but without my knowledge.
With their silver and gold they made idols
    for their own destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your calf is rejected, O Samaria.
    My anger burns against them.
How long will they be incapable of innocence?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For it is from Israel,
an artisan made it;
    it is not God.
The calf of Samaria
    shall be broken to pieces.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Though they bargain with the nations,
    I will now gather them up.
They shall soon writhe
    under the burden of kings and princes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Ephraim multiplied altars to expiate sin,
    they became to him altars for sinning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though I write for him the multitude of my instructions,
    they are regarded as a strange thing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though they offer choice sacrifices,
    though they eat flesh,
    the Lord does not accept them.
Now he will remember their iniquity
    and punish their sins;
    they shall return to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Israel has forgotten his Maker
    and built palaces,
and Judah has multiplied fortified cities,
    but I will send a fire upon his cities,
    and it shall devour his strongholds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not rejoice, O Israel!
    Do not exult as other nations do,
for you have prostituted yourself, departing from your God.
    You have loved a prostitute’s pay
    on all threshing floors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Threshing floor and wine vat shall not feed them,
    and the new wine shall fail them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They shall not remain in the land of the Lord,
    but Ephraim shall return to Egypt,
    and in Assyria they shall eat unclean food.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
What will you do on the day of appointed festival
    and on the day of the festival of the Lord?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The days of punishment have come;
    the days of recompense have come.
Israel will cry out,
“The prophet is a fool;
    the man of the spirit is mad!”
Because of your great iniquity,
    your hostility is great.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The prophet is a sentinel for my God over Ephraim,
yet a hunter’s snare is on all his ways
    and hostility in the house of his God.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Like grapes in the wilderness,
    I found Israel.
Like the first fruit on the fig tree,
    in its first season,
    I saw your ancestors.
But they came to Baal-peor
    and consecrated themselves to a thing of shame
    and became detestable like the thing they loved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ephraim’s glory shall fly away like a bird—
    no birth, no pregnancy, no conception!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even if they bring up children,
    I will bereave them until no one is left.
Woe to them indeed
    when I depart from them!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Once I saw Ephraim as a young palm planted in a lovely meadow,
    but now Ephraim must lead out his children for slaughter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give them, O Lord—
    what will you give?
Give them a miscarrying womb
    and dry breasts.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Ephraim is stricken,
    their root is dried up,
    they shall bear no fruit.
Even though they give birth,
    I will kill the cherished offspring of their womb.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Israel is a luxuriant vine
    that yields its fruit.
The more his fruit increased,
    the more altars he built;
as his country improved,
    he improved his pillars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their heart is false;
    now they must bear their guilt.
The Lord will break down their altars
    and destroy their pillars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For now they will say:
    “We have no king,
for we do not fear the Lord,
    and a king—what could he do for us?”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The inhabitants of Samaria tremble
    for the calf of Beth-aven.
Its people shall mourn for it,
    and its idolatrous priests shall wail over it,
    over its glory that has departed from it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The thing itself shall be carried to Assyria
    as tribute to the great king.
Ephraim shall be put to shame,
    and Israel shall be ashamed of his idol.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samaria’s king shall perish
    like a chip on the face of the waters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The high places of Aven, the sin of Israel,
    shall be destroyed.
Thorn and thistle shall grow up
    on their altars.
They shall say to the mountains, “Cover us,”
    and to the hills, “Fall on us.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I will come against the wayward people to punish them,
    and nations shall be gathered against them
    when they are punished for their double iniquity.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
therefore the tumult of war shall rise against your people,
    and all your fortresses shall be destroyed,
as Shalman destroyed Beth-arbel on the day of battle,
    when mothers were dashed in pieces with their children.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thus it shall be done to you, O Bethel,
    because of your great wickedness.
At dawn the king of Israel
    shall be utterly cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Israel was a child, I loved him,
    and out of Egypt I called my son.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The more I called them,
    the more they went from me;
they kept sacrificing to the Baals
    and offering incense to idols.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I led them with cords of human kindness,
    with bands of love.
I was to them like those
    who lift infants to their cheeks.
    I bent down to them and fed them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They shall return to the land of Egypt,
    and Assyria shall be their king,
    because they have refused to return to me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
My people are bent on turning away from me.
    To the Most High they call,
    but he does not raise them up at all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How can I give you up, Ephraim?
    How can I hand you over, O Israel?
How can I make you like Admah?
    How can I treat you like Zeboiim?
My heart recoils within me;
    my compassion grows warm and tender.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They shall go after the Lord,
    who roars like a lion;
when he roars,
    his children shall come trembling from the west.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They shall come trembling like birds from Egypt
    and like doves from the land of Assyria,
    and I will return them to their homes, says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ephraim has surrounded me with lies
    and the house of Israel with deceit,
but Judah still walks with God
    and is faithful to the Holy One.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The Lord has an indictment against Judah
    and will punish Jacob according to his ways
    and repay him according to his deeds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the womb he tried to supplant his brother,
    and in his manhood he strove with God.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The Lord the God of hosts,
    the Lord is his name!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
A trader in whose hands are false balances,
    he loves to oppress.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I am the Lord your God
    from the land of Egypt;
I will make you live in tents again,
    as in the days of the appointed festival.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
In Gilead there is iniquity;
    they shall surely come to nothing.
In Gilgal they sacrifice bulls,
    so their altars shall be like stone heaps
    on the furrows of the field.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
By a prophet the Lord brought Israel up from Egypt,
    and by a prophet he was guarded.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ephraim has given bitter offense,
    so his Lord will bring his crimes down on him
    and pay him back for his insults.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
And now they keep on sinning
    and make a cast image for themselves,
idols of silver made according to their understanding,
    all of them the work of artisans.
“Sacrifice to these,” they say.
    People are kissing calves!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore they shall be like the morning mist
    or like the dew that goes away early,
like chaff that swirls from the threshing floor
    or like smoke from a window.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet I have been the Lord your God
    ever since the land of Egypt;
you know no God but me,
    and besides me there is no savior.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It was I who fed you in the wilderness,
    in the land of drought.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
So I will become like a lion to them;
    like a leopard I will lurk beside the way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will fall upon them like a bear robbed of her cubs
    and will tear open the covering of their heart;
there I will devour them like a lion,
    as a wild animal would mangle them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will destroy you, O Israel;
    who can help you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where now is your king, that he may save you?
    Where in all your cities are your rulers,
of whom you said,
    “Give me a king and rulers”?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I gave you a king in my anger,
    and I took him away in my wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ephraim’s iniquity is bound up;
    his sin is kept in store.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The pangs of childbirth come for him,
    but he is an unwise son,
for at the proper time he does not present himself
    at the mouth of the womb.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shall I ransom them from the power of Sheol?
    Shall I redeem them from Death?
O Death, where are your plagues?
    O Sheol, where is your destruction?
    Compassion is hidden from my eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Although he may flourish among rushes,
    the east wind shall come, a blast from the Lord,
    rising from the wilderness,
and his fountain shall dry up;
    his spring shall be parched.
It shall strip his treasury
    of every precious thing.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Return, O Israel, to the Lord your God,
    for you have stumbled because of your iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take words with you
    and return to the Lord;
say to him,
    “Take away all guilt;
accept that which is good,
    and we will offer
    the fruit of our lips.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
O Ephraim, what have I to do with idols?
    It is I who answer and look after you.
I am like an evergreen cypress;
    your fruit comes from me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who are wise understand these things;
    those who are discerning know them.
For the ways of the Lord are right,
    and the upright walk in them,
    but transgressors stumble in them.
speaker: Narrator
